cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Which US President died in office in July 1850 to be succeeded by his Vice President Millard Fillmore?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
To solve the question, we need to identify the US President who died in office in July 1850. We know that Millard Fillmore was the Vice President who succeeded this President. Historically, we can recall that the President who died in office in July 1850 was Zachary Taylor. He served as the 12th President of the United States and passed away after a short time in office. Following his death, Millard Fillmore, who was serving as Vice President at the time, took over the presidency.

Answer:
Zachary Taylor

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Which US President died in office in July 1850 to be succeeded by his Vice President Millard Fillmore?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- July 9, 1850: President Taylor died and Vice President Millard Fillmore became President.\n', 'The presidency of Millard Fillmore began on July 9, 1850, when Millard Fillmore became President of the United States upon the death of Zachary Taylor, and ended on March 4, 1853. Fillmore had been Vice President of the United States for when he became the 13th United States president. Fillmore was the second president to succeed to the office without being elected to it, after John Tyler, as well as the last Whig president. Fillmore was succeeded by Democrat Franklin Pierce.\n', "Millard Fillmore (January 7, 1800 – March 8, 1874) was the 13th President of the United States, serving from 1850 until 1853. He became president upon the death of Zachary Taylor, under whom he had been the nation's 12th vice president, and was the last member of the Whig Party to serve as president.\n", 'BULLET::::- January 7 – Millard Fillmore, 13th President of the United States from 1850 till 1853, 12th Vice President of the United States from 1849 till 1850. (died in 1874)\n', "The Inauguration of Millard Fillmore, as the 13th President of the United States, was held on Wednesday, July 10, 1850 at the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C., following the death of President Zachary Taylor the previous day. Taylor died from a severe intestinal illness which subsequently thrust Millard Fillmore into the role of President . The inauguration marked the commencement of Millard Fillmore's only term (a partial term of ) as President, but he faced a stressful climate . There was political hubbub surrounding the Compromise of 1850 decision, which Fillmore had, days before Taylor's death, confessed that he was against his party when it came to this issue. Therefore, as he entered into the presidency, he found himself appointing an entirely new cabinet after Taylor's Cabinet members resigned . During the Inauguration, William Cranch, chief judge of the U.S. Circuit Court, administered the presidential oath of office to Fillmore in the chamber of the House of Representatives. Cranch had also administered the oath to John Tyler in 1841, when Tyler succeeded to the presidency upon William Henry Harrison's death. Millard Fillmore was the last president from neither the Democratic or Republican parties. \n", "Millard Fillmore (January 7, 1800 – March 8, 1874) was the 13th president of the United States (1850–1853), the last to be a member of the Whig Party while in the White House. A former U.S. representative from New York, Fillmore was elected the nation's 12th vice president in 1848, and succeeded to the presidency in July 1850 upon the death of President Zachary Taylor. He was instrumental in getting the Compromise of 1850 passed, a bargain that led to a brief truce in the battle over slavery. He failed to win the Whig nomination for president in 1852; he gained the endorsement of the nativist Know Nothing Party four years later, and finished third in that election.\n", 'BULLET::::- Millard Fillmore becomes the 13th President of the United States upon the death of President Zachary Taylor on July 9, 1850\n', 'BULLET::::- March 8 – Millard Fillmore, 13th President of the U.S. from 1850 to 1853, and 12th Vice President of the U.S. from 1849 to 1850 (born 1800)\n', 'BULLET::::- Millard Fillmore, (1800–1874) was the 13th President of the United States, serving from 1850 until 1853 and the last member of the Whig Party (United States) to hold that office.\n', 'BULLET::::- In the short story "Now Falls the Cold, Cold Night" by Jack L. Chalker, also contained in the anthology "Alternate Presidents" by Mike Resnick, Millard Fillmore was elected the Know Nothing Party candidate in 1856, defeating the Democratic candidate James Buchanan and the Republican candidate John C. Frémont. He therefore became the 15th President, having previously served as the 13th President from 1850 to 1853 as a member of the Whig Party. His vice president was Andrew Jackson Donelson, the namesake nephew of former President Andrew Jackson. When Fillmore upholds the Fugitive slave laws in 1858, this resulted in ethnic tensions and riots in New England that lead it to succeed from the Union. John C. Frémont becomes President of the New England Confederacy with William Tecumseh Sherman as his commanding general, opposed by the Army of the United States under Robert E. Lee.\n']

Task Description:

which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts,

To answer the question about which US President died in office in July 1850 and was succeeded by Vice President Millard Fillmore, the passages provide several key pieces of information that may be unfamiliar or require clarification for a deeper understanding. Here’s an analysis of the relevant content extracted from the passages:

1. **Zachary Taylor's Presidency**:
   - **Role**: Understanding who Zachary Taylor was is crucial, as he was the 12th President of the United States and the individual who died in office. His presidency lasted from March 4, 1849, until his death on July 9, 1850.
   - **Context**: Taylor's presidency was marked by significant political tensions, particularly regarding the issue of slavery, which would later be addressed in the Compromise of 1850.

2. **Millard Fillmore's Succession**:
   - **Role**: Millard Fillmore became the 13th President upon Taylor's death. This transition is significant in understanding the continuity of leadership during a tumultuous period in American history.
   - **Context**: Fillmore's ascension to the presidency without being elected (he was Vice President) is a notable aspect of American political history, as it highlights the mechanisms of presidential succession.

3. **The Compromise of 1850**:
   - **Role**: This legislative package was crucial in addressing the sectional conflicts between the North and South over slavery. Fillmore played a significant role in its passage, which is important for understanding the political climate of the time.
   - **Context**: The Compromise of 1850 included measures that aimed to balance the interests of slave and free states, reflecting the growing tensions that would eventually lead to the Civil War.

4. **Political Parties**:
   - **Role**: Fillmore was the last president from the Whig Party, which is essential for understanding the evolution of political parties in the United States. His presidency marked the decline of the Whig Party and the rise of the Republican Party.
   - **Context**: The mention of Fillmore's affiliation with the Know Nothing Party later in his career also illustrates the shifting political landscape of the era.

5. **Historical Context of the Era**:
   - **Role**: The period leading up to the Civil War was fraught with political strife, particularly over issues of slavery and state rights. Understanding this context helps frame the significance of Fillmore's presidency and the challenges he faced.
   - **Context**: The political hubbub surrounding the Compromise of 1850 and Fillmore's initial opposition to it provides insight into the complexities of governance during this period.

In summary, the extracted content provides a rich background that enhances understanding of the question. It contextualizes the events surrounding the death of Zachary Taylor, the succession of Millard Fillmore, and the political dynamics of the time. This knowledge is essential for grasping the implications of Fillmore's presidency and the historical significance of the events that unfolded during that era.

Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

To solve the question regarding which US President died in office in July 1850 and was succeeded by Vice President Millard Fillmore, we begin by identifying the key figures involved and the historical context surrounding their presidencies.

1. **Identifying Zachary Taylor**:
   - Zachary Taylor served as the 12th President of the United States from March 4, 1849, until his death on July 9, 1850. His presidency was relatively short, lasting just over a year, and he is notable for being a military leader before entering politics.
   - Understanding Taylor's background is essential, as it provides insight into his leadership style and the challenges he faced during his presidency, particularly regarding the contentious issue of slavery.

2. **Millard Fillmore's Role**:
   - Millard Fillmore was the Vice President under Taylor and became the 13th President upon Taylor's death. This transition is significant as it illustrates the process of presidential succession in the United States, which is governed by the Constitution.
   - Fillmore's presidency marked a critical period in American history, as he took office during a time of intense national debate over slavery and state rights, which would eventually lead to the Civil War.

3. **The Compromise of 1850**:
   - Fillmore played a pivotal role in the passage of the Compromise of 1850, a series of legislative measures aimed at easing tensions between slave and free states. This context is crucial for understanding the political landscape of the time and Fillmore's approach to governance.
   - The Compromise included provisions such as the admission of California as a free state and the strengthening of the Fugitive Slave Act, which were contentious issues that highlighted the deep divisions within the country.

4. **Political Dynamics**:
   - Fillmore was the last president from the Whig Party, which is important for understanding the evolution of political parties in the United States. His presidency coincided with the decline of the Whig Party and the emergence of the Republican Party, reflecting the shifting political allegiances of the era.
   - The mention of Fillmore's later affiliation with the Know Nothing Party further illustrates the complexities of political identity and the changing landscape of American politics during the mid-19th century.

5. **Historical Context**:
   - The period leading up to the Civil War was marked by significant political strife, particularly over issues of slavery, territorial expansion, and states' rights. Understanding this context helps frame the significance of Fillmore's presidency and the challenges he faced in unifying a divided nation.
   - The political turmoil surrounding the Compromise of 1850 and Fillmore's initial opposition to certain aspects of it provides insight into the complexities of governance during this tumultuous period.

In summary, the enhanced reasoning process incorporates a comprehensive understanding of the historical figures involved, the political context of the time, and the implications of their actions. This background knowledge is essential for accurately answering the question about the President who died in office in July 1850.

**Answer:**
Zachary Taylor

To answer the question regarding which US President died in office in July 1850 and was succeeded by his Vice President Millard Fillmore, we can extract and analyze relevant information from the provided passages.

### Key Information Extracted:

1. **Zachary Taylor's Death**: The passages consistently indicate that President Zachary Taylor died on July 9, 1850. This is a crucial detail as it directly answers the question about the president who died in office during that time.

2. **Succession by Millard Fillmore**: Following Taylor's death, Vice President Millard Fillmore ascended to the presidency. This transition is highlighted in multiple passages, confirming Fillmore's role as the 13th President of the United States, succeeding Taylor.

3. **Context of Fillmore's Presidency**: The passages provide additional context about Fillmore's presidency, noting that he was the last president from the Whig Party and that his term began under challenging political circumstances, particularly surrounding the Compromise of 1850. This context enriches our understanding of the political landscape at the time of Taylor's death and Fillmore's subsequent presidency.

4. **Inauguration Details**: Fillmore's inauguration took place on July 10, 1850, the day after Taylor's death. This detail emphasizes the immediate transition of power and the urgency of the political situation following the president's demise.

5. **Historical Significance**: The information also notes that Fillmore was the second president to succeed without being elected to the presidency, following John Tyler. This highlights the historical precedent of vice presidents stepping into the role due to the death of a sitting president.

### Contextual Relationships:

- **Causality**: The death of Zachary Taylor is the direct cause of Millard Fillmore's ascension to the presidency. This relationship is critical to understanding the political dynamics of the time.
  
- **Political Landscape**: The context surrounding Fillmore's presidency, including his previous role as vice president and the challenges he faced, illustrates the complexities of leadership during a period of national tension over issues such as slavery.

- **Historical Precedent**: Fillmore's succession is part of a broader historical pattern where vice presidents take over after the death of a president, which is significant in the study of U.S. political history.

### Summary:

In summary, the US President who died in office in July 1850 was Zachary Taylor, who passed away on July 9. He was succeeded by his Vice President, Millard Fillmore, who became the 13th President of the United States. This transition occurred under significant political pressure, particularly regarding the Compromise of 1850, marking a pivotal moment in U.S. history. Understanding these relationships and contexts provides a comprehensive answer to the question, highlighting the importance of both the event (Taylor's death) and the subsequent political implications (Fillmore's presidency).

To address the question of which US President died in office in July 1850 and was succeeded by his Vice President Millard Fillmore, we begin by identifying the key figures involved and the timeline of events surrounding this transition.

Historical knowledge indicates that this president was Zachary Taylor, who served as the 12th President of the United States. His death on July 9, 1850, is a critical detail that directly answers the question.

2. **Succession Details**: Following Taylor's death, Millard Fillmore, who was serving as Vice President at the time, ascended to the presidency. This transition is significant as it illustrates the constitutional process of succession, where the Vice President takes over when the sitting president can no longer fulfill their duties.

3. **Context of Fillmore's Presidency**: The passages provide context about Fillmore's presidency, noting that he was the last president from the Whig Party and that his term began during a tumultuous period in American politics, particularly concerning the Compromise of 1850. This context is essential for understanding the challenges Fillmore faced as he took office, including the political climate surrounding issues of slavery and sectional tensions.

4. **Inauguration and Immediate Impact**: Fillmore's inauguration took place on July 10, 1850, just one day after Taylor's death. This detail underscores the urgency of the situation and the immediate need for leadership during a time of uncertainty. The rapid transition of power is a crucial aspect of the historical narrative.

5. **Historical Significance**: Fillmore's ascension to the presidency is notable not only for the circumstances of Taylor's death but also because he was the second president to succeed without being elected to the presidency, following John Tyler. This historical precedent highlights the role of vice presidents in maintaining governmental continuity during crises.

### Contextual Relationships:

- **Causality**: The direct cause of Millard Fillmore's presidency was the death of Zachary Taylor. This relationship is fundamental to understanding the political dynamics of the time and the implications of such a succession.

- **Political Landscape**: The context surrounding Fillmore's presidency, including his previous role as vice president and the political challenges he faced, illustrates the complexities of leadership during a period marked by national division over slavery and other issues.

- **Historical Precedent**: Fillmore's succession reflects a broader historical pattern in U.S. politics where vice presidents assume the presidency due to the death or resignation of a sitting president. This pattern is significant for understanding the stability and continuity of the U.S. government.

### Conclusion:

In summary, the US President who died in office in July 1850 was Zachary Taylor, who passed away on July 9. He was succeeded by his Vice President, Millard Fillmore, who became the 13th President of the United States. This transition occurred under significant political pressure, particularly regarding the Compromise of 1850, marking a pivotal moment in U.S. history. Understanding these relationships and contexts provides a comprehensive answer to the question, highlighting the importance of both the event (Taylor's death) and the subsequent political implications (Fillmore's presidency).

Zachary Taylor

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate key information from the provided passages regarding the events surrounding the death of President Zachary Taylor and the subsequent succession of Millard Fillmore. Here’s a breakdown of the relevant information:

### Extracted Information:
1. **Date of Death**: Zachary Taylor died on July 9, 1850.
2. **Succession**: Millard Fillmore, who was the Vice President at the time, succeeded Taylor as President immediately following his death.
3. **Inauguration**: Fillmore's inauguration took place on July 10, 1850.
4. **Political Context**: Taylor's death occurred amid political tensions regarding the Compromise of 1850, which Fillmore had expressed opposition to prior to Taylor's death.
5. **Historical Significance**: Fillmore was the last president from the Whig Party and the second president to assume office without being elected, following John Tyler.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Cause and Effect**: The model can learn to identify the causal relationship between Taylor's death and Fillmore's ascension to the presidency. This is a clear cause (death of a sitting president) leading to an effect (the Vice President becoming President).

2. **Temporal Sequencing**: The model can improve its ability to understand sequences of events. The timeline of Taylor's death followed by Fillmore's inauguration provides a clear example of how one event can lead to another in a specific order.

3. **Political Dynamics**: The context surrounding Taylor's death, particularly the political climate regarding the Compromise of 1850, allows the model to infer how external factors (political tensions) can influence leadership transitions and decision-making processes in government.

4. **Role of Vice Presidents**: The information highlights the constitutional role of the Vice President in succession scenarios, which can help the model understand the implications of political roles and responsibilities in governance.

5. **Historical Context**: Recognizing Fillmore as the last Whig president adds depth to the model's understanding of political party dynamics and historical significance, which can inform future reasoning about political transitions and their implications.

### Conclusion:
By consolidating these key pieces of information, the model can enhance its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. It will be better equipped to analyze sequences of events, understand the implications of political roles, and recognize the significance of historical contexts in shaping political outcomes. This understanding can be applied to a broader range of scenarios beyond this specific historical event, improving the model's overall reasoning abilities.

Historically, we can recall that the President who died in office in July 1850 was Zachary Taylor. He served as the 12th President of the United States and passed away after a short time in office. Following his death, Millard Fillmore, who was serving as Vice President at the time, took over the presidency.

Answer:
Zachary Taylor

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:
To solve the question of which US President died in office in July 1850 and was succeeded by his Vice President Millard Fillmore, we can follow a structured reasoning process:

1. **Identify the President**: We need to determine which President died in July 1850. Historical knowledge indicates that Zachary Taylor was the 12th President of the United States and he died in office on July 9, 1850.

2. **Succession Details**: Upon Taylor's death, Millard Fillmore, who was serving as Vice President, succeeded him. This is a crucial point as it establishes the direct relationship between the events of Taylor's death and Fillmore's ascension to the presidency.

3. **Inauguration Timing**: Fillmore's formal inauguration as President occurred the day after Taylor's death, on July 10, 1850. This highlights the immediate succession process defined by the U.S. Constitution.

4. **Political Context**: Taylor's death occurred during a politically charged atmosphere, particularly regarding the Compromise of 1850, which was a significant legislative effort to address issues related to slavery and territorial expansion. Fillmore's prior opposition to certain aspects of this compromise adds depth to the understanding of his presidency and the challenges he faced.

5. **Historical Significance**: Fillmore's presidency is notable as he was the last president from the Whig Party and the second president to assume office without being elected, following John Tyler. This context is important for understanding the political landscape of the time and the implications of party dynamics.

6. **Causal Relationships**: The model can learn to identify the cause (the death of Zachary Taylor) and the effect (Millard Fillmore becoming President). This relationship is foundational for understanding political succession in the U.S. government.

7. **Temporal Sequencing**: The sequence of events—Taylor's death leading to Fillmore's inauguration—illustrates how one event can trigger another, reinforcing the model's ability to understand chronological order and its significance in historical events.

8. **Implications of Political Roles**: Understanding the role of the Vice President in succession scenarios enhances the model's grasp of governance and the constitutional framework that guides leadership transitions.

### Conclusion:
By synthesizing these elements, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. It will be better equipped to analyze political events, understand the implications of leadership changes, and recognize the significance of historical contexts in shaping political outcomes.

### Answer:
Zachary Taylor

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
Which US President died in office in July 1850 to be succeeded by his Vice President Millard Fillmore?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- July 9, 1850: President Taylor died and Vice President Millard Fillmore became President.\n', 'The presidency of Millard Fillmore began on July 9, 1850, when Millard Fillmore became President of the United States upon the death of Zachary Taylor, and ended on March 4, 1853. Fillmore had been Vice President of the United States for when he became the 13th United States president. Fillmore was the second president to succeed to the office without being elected to it, after John Tyler, as well as the last Whig president. Fillmore was succeeded by Democrat Franklin Pierce.\n', "Millard Fillmore (January 7, 1800 – March 8, 1874) was the 13th President of the United States, serving from 1850 until 1853. He became president upon the death of Zachary Taylor, under whom he had been the nation's 12th vice president, and was the last member of the Whig Party to serve as president.\n", 'BULLET::::- January 7 – Millard Fillmore, 13th President of the United States from 1850 till 1853, 12th Vice President of the United States from 1849 till 1850. (died in 1874)\n', "The Inauguration of Millard Fillmore, as the 13th President of the United States, was held on Wednesday, July 10, 1850 at the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C., following the death of President Zachary Taylor the previous day. Taylor died from a severe intestinal illness which subsequently thrust Millard Fillmore into the role of President . The inauguration marked the commencement of Millard Fillmore's only term (a partial term of ) as President, but he faced a stressful climate . There was political hubbub surrounding the Compromise of 1850 decision, which Fillmore had, days before Taylor's death, confessed that he was against his party when it came to this issue. Therefore, as he entered into the presidency, he found himself appointing an entirely new cabinet after Taylor's Cabinet members resigned . During the Inauguration, William Cranch, chief judge of the U.S. Circuit Court, administered the presidential oath of office to Fillmore in the chamber of the House of Representatives. Cranch had also administered the oath to John Tyler in 1841, when Tyler succeeded to the presidency upon William Henry Harrison's death. Millard Fillmore was the last president from neither the Democratic or Republican parties. \n", "Millard Fillmore (January 7, 1800 – March 8, 1874) was the 13th president of the United States (1850–1853), the last to be a member of the Whig Party while in the White House. A former U.S. representative from New York, Fillmore was elected the nation's 12th vice president in 1848, and succeeded to the presidency in July 1850 upon the death of President Zachary Taylor. He was instrumental in getting the Compromise of 1850 passed, a bargain that led to a brief truce in the battle over slavery. He failed to win the Whig nomination for president in 1852; he gained the endorsement of the nativist Know Nothing Party four years later, and finished third in that election.\n", 'BULLET::::- Millard Fillmore becomes the 13th President of the United States upon the death of President Zachary Taylor on July 9, 1850\n', 'BULLET::::- March 8 – Millard Fillmore, 13th President of the U.S. from 1850 to 1853, and 12th Vice President of the U.S. from 1849 to 1850 (born 1800)\n', 'BULLET::::- Millard Fillmore, (1800–1874) was the 13th President of the United States, serving from 1850 until 1853 and the last member of the Whig Party (United States) to hold that office.\n', 'BULLET::::- In the short story "Now Falls the Cold, Cold Night" by Jack L. Chalker, also contained in the anthology "Alternate Presidents" by Mike Resnick, Millard Fillmore was elected the Know Nothing Party candidate in 1856, defeating the Democratic candidate James Buchanan and the Republican candidate John C. Frémont. He therefore became the 15th President, having previously served as the 13th President from 1850 to 1853 as a member of the Whig Party. His vice president was Andrew Jackson Donelson, the namesake nephew of former President Andrew Jackson. When Fillmore upholds the Fugitive slave laws in 1858, this resulted in ethnic tensions and riots in New England that lead it to succeed from the Union. John C. Frémont becomes President of the New England Confederacy with William Tecumseh Sherman as his commanding general, opposed by the Army of the United States under Robert E. Lee.\n']

question_info.question: Which US President died in office in July 1850 to be succeeded by his Vice President Millard Fillmore?
passages:
BULLET::::- July 9, 1850: President Taylor died and Vice President Millard Fillmore became President.
The presidency of Millard Fillmore began on July 9, 1850, when Millard Fillmore became President of the United States upon the death of Zachary Taylor, and ended on March 4, 1853. Fillmore had been Vice President of the United States for when he became the 13th United States president. Fillmore was the second president to succeed to the office without being elected to it, after John Tyler, as well as the last Whig president. Fillmore was succeeded by Democrat Franklin Pierce.
Millard Fillmore (January 7, 1800 – March 8, 1874) was the 13th President of the United States, serving from 1850 until 1853. He became president upon the death of Zachary Taylor, under whom he had been the nation's 12th vice president, and was the last member of the Whig Party to serve as president.
BULLET::::- January 7 – Millard Fillmore, 13th President of the United States from 1850 till 1853, 12th Vice President of the United States from 1849 till 1850. (died in 1874)
The Inauguration of Millard Fillmore, as the 13th President of the United States, was held on Wednesday, July 10, 1850 at the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C., following the death of President Zachary Taylor the previous day. Taylor died from a severe intestinal illness which subsequently thrust Millard Fillmore into the role of President . The inauguration marked the commencement of Millard Fillmore's only term (a partial term of ) as President, but he faced a stressful climate . There was political hubbub surrounding the Compromise of 1850 decision, which Fillmore had, days before Taylor's death, confessed that he was against his party when it came to this issue. Therefore, as he entered into the presidency, he found himself appointing an entirely new cabinet after Taylor's Cabinet members resigned . During the Inauguration, William Cranch, chief judge of the U.S. Circuit Court, administered the presidential oath of office to Fillmore in the chamber of the House of Representatives. Cranch had also administered the oath to John Tyler in 1841, when Tyler succeeded to the presidency upon William Henry Harrison's death. Millard Fillmore was the last president from neither the Democratic or Republican parties. 
Millard Fillmore (January 7, 1800 – March 8, 1874) was the 13th president of the United States (1850–1853), the last to be a member of the Whig Party while in the White House. A former U.S. representative from New York, Fillmore was elected the nation's 12th vice president in 1848, and succeeded to the presidency in July 1850 upon the death of President Zachary Taylor. He was instrumental in getting the Compromise of 1850 passed, a bargain that led to a brief truce in the battle over slavery. He failed to win the Whig nomination for president in 1852; he gained the endorsement of the nativist Know Nothing Party four years later, and finished third in that election.
BULLET::::- Millard Fillmore becomes the 13th President of the United States upon the death of President Zachary Taylor on July 9, 1850
BULLET::::- March 8 – Millard Fillmore, 13th President of the U.S. from 1850 to 1853, and 12th Vice President of the U.S. from 1849 to 1850 (born 1800)
BULLET::::- Millard Fillmore, (1800–1874) was the 13th President of the United States, serving from 1850 until 1853 and the last member of the Whig Party (United States) to hold that office.
BULLET::::- In the short story "Now Falls the Cold, Cold Night" by Jack L. Chalker, also contained in the anthology "Alternate Presidents" by Mike Resnick, Millard Fillmore was elected the Know Nothing Party candidate in 1856, defeating the Democratic candidate James Buchanan and the Republican candidate John C. Frémont. He therefore became the 15th President, having previously served as the 13th President from 1850 to 1853 as a member of the Whig Party. His vice president was Andrew Jackson Donelson, the namesake nephew of former President Andrew Jackson. When Fillmore upholds the Fugitive slave laws in 1858, this resulted in ethnic tensions and riots in New England that lead it to succeed from the Union. John C. Frémont becomes President of the New England Confederacy with William Tecumseh Sherman as his commanding general, opposed by the Army of the United States under Robert E. Lee.
